\chapter{Howtos}
\label{index:welcome-to-listb-s-documentation}\label{index:howtos}

\section{Getting the data}
\label{howtos/getting_the_data::doc}\label{howtos/getting_the_data:getting-the-data}
I used the following workflow to access all papers of S. Shelah listed on
`MathSciNet'

First I retrieve the MR-numbers. I use the \code{mrnumbers} command from
\code{mrtools.py}. The option \code{-{-}url} should point to a search result from
`MathSciNet'. The option \code{-{-}crawl} specifies, that I want the results from
all pages and finally I specify where I want to dump the list of MR-numbers.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{} mrtools.py mrnumbers \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}crawl \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}dump files/mrnumbers.yaml \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}url \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYGZgt{} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}http://tinyurl.com/shelahmsn\PYGZdq{}}
\end{Verbatim}

Next I will access the bib-files associated to these numbers. For this purpose
I am using the \code{bib} command.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{} mrtools.py bib \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}load files/mrnumbers.yaml \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}dump files/msn.bib
\end{Verbatim}

Now that I have the bibliographic data from `MathSciNet', I am going to create
the merge keys. This can be done using \code{pybibtools.py} with the \code{make-key}
command. The option \code{-k} tells the script which fields should be used for the
key creation. There are to special values for \code{-k}, namely \code{normauthor} and
\code{normtitle}. They call {\hyperref[modules/normalizetex:listb.normalizetex.norm_author]{\crossref{\code{listb.normalizetex.norm\_author()}}}} or
{\hyperref[modules/normalizetex:listb.normalizetex.norm_title]{\crossref{\code{listb.normalizetex.norm\_title()}}}} resp. and add these fields to the
bibliography.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{} pybibtools.py make\PYGZhy{}key \PYGZhy{}k normauthor \PYGZhy{}k year \PYGZhy{}k normtitle \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYGZgt{} \PYGZhy{}o files/norm\PYGZus{}msn.bib files/msn.bib
\end{Verbatim}

Now let's do the same for `listb'.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{} pybibtools.py make\PYGZhy{}key \PYGZhy{}k normauthor \PYGZhy{}k year \PYGZhy{}k normtitle \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYGZgt{} \PYGZhy{}o files/norm\PYGZus{}listb.bib files/listb.bib
\end{Verbatim}

This raises a \code{RuntimeError} if the generated keys are not unique. If so a
note is taken in the respective `info' file.

Finally, we are able to merge the datasets.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{} pybibtools.py merge \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}left \PYGZhy{}o files/merged.bib \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYGZgt{} files/norm\PYGZus{}listb.bib files/norm\PYGZus{}msn.bib
\end{Verbatim}

Note that the \code{merge} command is \emph{not} commutative.

Here is some data of the first trial run. The last column indicates that 842
entries could be matched.
\begin{quote}

\begin{tabulary}{\linewidth}{|L|L|L|L|}
\hline
\textsf{\relax 
\#
} & \textsf{\relax 
entries
} & \textsf{\relax 
with URL
} & \textsf{\relax 
with MR-no.
}\\
\hline

 &

 &

 &

\\
\hline

 &

 &

\\

 &

 &

 &

\\
\hline\end{tabulary}

\end{quote}

\section{mrtools.py}
\label{scripts/mrtools:mrtools-py}\label{scripts/mrtools::doc}\label{scripts/mrtools:module-scripts.mrtools}\index{scripts.mrtools (module)}
Small command line tools for accessing bibliographic data from `MathSciNet'.
\index{chunk\_list() (in module scripts.mrtools)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{scripts/mrtools:scripts.mrtools.chunk_list}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{scripts.mrtools.}\bfcode{chunk\_list}}{\emph{l}, \emph{n}}{}
Chops a list into tuples (chunks) of maximal size \titleref{n}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\textbf{\texttt{l}} (\emph{\texttt{List{[}Any{]}}}) -- the list to be resized

\item {} 
\textbf{\texttt{n}} (\emph{\texttt{int}}) -- maximal size of the chunks

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}
\paragraph{Example}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{chunk\PYGZus{}list}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{[(1, 2), (3, 4), (5,)]}
\end{Verbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\chapter{Modules}
\label{index:modules}

\section{mrtools}
\label{modules/mrtools::doc}\label{modules/mrtools:module-listb.mrtools}\label{modules/mrtools:mrtools}\index{listb.mrtools (module)}
Python functions for accessing search results from MathSciNet and
downloading BibTeX bibliographies associated to the results
\index{crawl() (in module listb.mrtools)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/mrtools:listb.mrtools.crawl}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{listb.mrtools.}\bfcode{crawl}}{\emph{url}}{}
Crawls specified URL on MathSciNet

If the search result is split into 5 pages and the URL to page
3 is passed then the source codes and URLs of pages 3, 4, and 5
are returned.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{\texttt{url}} (\emph{\texttt{str}}) -- URL pointing to a search page on MathSciNet

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
List of page source codes and list of URLs

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
(List{[}str{]}, List{[}str{]})

\end{description}\end{quote}

\begin{notice}{note}{Note:}
To use this fuction you need to have access to MathSciNet.
\end{notice}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{get\_bibtex\_from\_msn() (in module listb.mrtools)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/mrtools:listb.mrtools.get_bibtex_from_msn}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{listb.mrtools.}\bfcode{get\_bibtex\_from\_msn}}{\emph{mrnumbers}, \emph{outfile=None}}{}
Fetches BibTeX file from MathSciNet server using the MR-numbers
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\textbf{\texttt{mrnumbers}} (\emph{\texttt{List{[}str{]}}}) -- the BibTeX entries for these MR-numbers are retrieved

\item {} 
\textbf{\texttt{outfile}} (\emph{\texttt{Opitonal{[}str{]}}}) -- path to output file

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
BibTeX file as string

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
str

\end{description}\end{quote}

\begin{notice}{note}{Note:}
To use this fuction you need to have access to MathSciNet.
\end{notice}
\paragraph{Example}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}bibtex\PYGZus{}from\PYGZus{}msn}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{0241312}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)} 
\PYG{g+go}{@article \PYGZob{}MR0241312,}
\PYG{g+go}{    AUTHOR = \PYGZob{}Shelah, Saharon\PYGZcb{},}
\PYG{g+go}{     TITLE = \PYGZob{}Note on a min\PYGZhy{}max problem of \PYGZob{}L\PYGZcb{}eo \PYGZob{}M\PYGZcb{}oser\PYGZcb{},}
\PYG{g+go}{   JOURNAL = \PYGZob{}J. Combinatorial Theory\PYGZcb{},}
\PYG{g+go}{    VOLUME = \PYGZob{}6\PYGZcb{},}
\PYG{g+go}{      YEAR = \PYGZob{}1969\PYGZcb{},}
\PYG{g+go}{     PAGES = \PYGZob{}298\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}300\PYGZcb{},}
\PYG{g+go}{   MRCLASS = \PYGZob{}05.04\PYGZcb{},}
\PYG{g+go}{  MRNUMBER = \PYGZob{}0241312\PYGZcb{},}
\PYG{g+go}{MRREVIEWER = \PYGZob{}G. F. Clements\PYGZcb{},}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{Verbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{get\_mrnumber() (in module listb.mrtools)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/mrtools:listb.mrtools.get_mrnumber}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{listb.mrtools.}\bfcode{get\_mrnumber}}{\emph{doc}}{}
Extracts MR-number from the ``headlineText'' of the search result
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{\texttt{doc}} (\emph{\texttt{bs4.element.Tag}}) -- headlineText

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
MR-number

\section{pybibtools}
\label{modules/pybibtools:module-listb.pybibtools}\label{modules/pybibtools::doc}\label{modules/pybibtools:pybibtools}\index{listb.pybibtools (module)}
Functions for handling bibliograhic databases

A workflow of special interest is merging to bibliographies. The example below
creates two {\hyperref[modules/pybibtools:listb.pybibtools.Bibliography]{\crossref{\code{Bibliography}}}} objects from two databases, that are not
disjoint. The first database contains some data we want to keep, but the second
database contains some additional information.

Note how in the first call to \code{merge()} the new dataset contains 3 entries
and the ``ID'' field remains unchanged. In the second call to \code{merge()} the
resulting bibliography has only two entries, namly its initial ones. However,
the field ``url'' from the second database is present.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{data1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{year}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{1981}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }          \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{title}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Weak compactness and the structure}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }          \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{author}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Sageev, G. and Shelah, S.}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }          \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ENTRYTYPE}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{incollection}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }          \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ID}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{MR645920}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }         \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }         \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{year}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{1981}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }          \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{title}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Iterated forcing and changing cofinalities}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }          \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{author}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Shelah, Saharon}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }          \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ENTRYTYPE}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{article}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }          \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ID}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{MR636904}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }         \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }        \PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{data2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{year}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{1981}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }          \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{title}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Iterated forcing and changing cofinalities}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}

\index{add\_fields() (listb.pybibtools.Bibliography method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/pybibtools:listb.pybibtools.Bibliography.add_fields}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{add\_fields}}{\emph{**kargs}}{}
Adds fields to bibliography
For each entry of \code{kargs} a field corresponding to the key
of the entry is added. The value of the entry must be a
unary function accepting an entry of the bibliography as its
argument.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{\texttt{kargs}} (\emph{\texttt{Dict{[}str, function{]}}}) -- Dictionary of field names and construction functions

\end{description}\end{quote}
\paragraph{Example}

In this example the author field is concatenated with itself
and stored in the field `doubleauthor'.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\index{data (listb.pybibtools.Bibliography attribute)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/pybibtools:listb.pybibtools.Bibliography.data}\pysigline{\bfcode{data}}
Property containing the bibliographic data
\code{data} must be a list of entries, where each entry
is a \code{dict} containing the keys ``ENTRYTYPE'' and ``ID''.
These ID-s must be unique.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Raises}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{RuntimeError} -- if fields are missing or the ID-s are not unique

\item {} 
\code{TypeError} -- if \code{data} is of incorrect type

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}
\paragraph{Example}

The first example raises an error since the argument supplied
to \code{data} is not of correct type. The second example
succeeds.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{bib} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Bibliography}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{bib}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{data}
\PYG{g+go}{[]}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{bib}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Katze}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{g+gt}{Traceback (most recent call last):}
  \PYG{c}{...}
\PYG{g+gr}{TypeError}: \PYG{n}{Expected data as list of bibliographic entries got}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZlt{}class \PYGZsq{}str\PYGZsq{}\PYGZgt{}}

\index{load() (listb.pybibtools.Bibliography method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/pybibtools:listb.pybibtools.Bibliography.load}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{load}}{\emph{handle}, \emph{reader='yaml'}}{}
Loads bibliography from handle
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\textbf{\texttt{handle}} (\emph{\texttt{handle}}) -- file handle of biblography

\item {} 
\textbf{\texttt{reader}} (\emph{\texttt{Optional{[}str{]}}}) -- name of reader (see {\hyperref[modules/pybibtools:listb.pybibtools.Bibliography.READERS]{\crossref{\code{READERS}}}})

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}
\paragraph{Example}

Assuming that the file `bib.yaml' exists, one can
load its data into a bibliography as follows.
\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{} bib = Bibliography() \# doctest: +SKIP
\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{} with open(`bib.yaml', `r') as handle: \# doctest: +SKIP
...     bib.load(handle, reader='yaml')

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{make\_key() (listb.pybibtools.Bibliography method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/pybibtools:listb.pybibtools.Bibliography.make_key}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{make\_key}}{\emph{*keys}}{}
Creates a merge key formed out of the fields specified
in \code{keys}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{\texttt{keys}} (\emph{\texttt{List{[}str{]}}}) -- List of field names

\item[{Raises}] \leavevmode
\code{RuntimeError} -- if the merge keys are not unique

\end{description}\end{quote}
\paragraph{Example}

Note how the first example produces a \code{RuntimeError} since
the years coincide. Using a combination of author and year
fixes this.

\index{merge() (listb.pybibtools.Bibliography method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/pybibtools:listb.pybibtools.Bibliography.merge}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{merge}}{\emph{other}, \emph{union=True}, \emph{keep\_key=False}}{}
Merges two bibliographies using the merge key in field
{\hyperref[modules/pybibtools:listb.pybibtools.Bibliography.MERGEKEY]{\crossref{\code{MERGEKEY}}}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\textbf{\texttt{other}} ({\hyperref[modules/pybibtools:listb.pybibtools.Bibliography]{\crossref{\emph{\texttt{Bibliography}}}}}) -- The bibliography to be merged

\item {} 
\textbf{\texttt{union}} (\emph{\texttt{Optional{[}bool{]}}}) -- Do you want the new database to contain the union
of the keys? Otherwise only the entries of the left
bibliography will be updated and entries not contained
in it will be ignored. Defaults to \code{True}

\item {} 
\textbf{\texttt{keep\_key}} (\emph{\texttt{Optional{[}bool{]}}}) -- Do you want to keep the merge key? Defaults to \code{False}

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
Bibliography containing the merged dataset

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
{\hyperref[modules/pybibtools:listb.pybibtools.Bibliography]{\crossref{Bibliography}}}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{union() (listb.pybibtools.Bibliography method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/pybibtools:listb.pybibtools.Bibliography.union}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{union}}{\emph{other}}{}
Returns the union of two bibliographies.

This is a special case of {\hyperref[modules/pybibtools:listb.pybibtools.Bibliography.merge]{\crossref{\code{merge()}}}} were the merge key is just
the field `ID'
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{\texttt{other}} ({\hyperref[modules/pybibtools:listb.pybibtools.Bibliography]{\crossref{\emph{\texttt{Bibliography}}}}}) -- bibliography to be joined

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
union of the bibliographies entries

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
{\hyperref[modules/pybibtools:listb.pybibtools.Bibliography]{\crossref{Bibliography}}}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\begin{notice}{note}{Note:}
\code{union} is \emph{not} commutative. See example below.
\end{notice}
\paragraph{Example}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
